<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Poverty skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Poverty</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jakarta_slumhome_2.jpg" title="File:Jakarta slumhome 2.jpg">File:Jakarta slumhome 2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">An example of urban poverty in this <a href="/wiki/Slum" title="Slum">slum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jakarta" title="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a></div></div></div>
<p><b>Poverty</b>  is  scarcity, dearth, or the state of one who lacks a certain amount of material possessions or money.<sup id="cite_ref-webster_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-webster-1">[1]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Extreme_poverty" title="Extreme poverty">Absolute poverty</a> or <b>destitution</b> refers to the deprivation of <a href="/wiki/Basic_needs" title="Basic needs">basic human needs</a>, which commonly includes food, <a href="/wiki/Drinking_water" title="Drinking water">water</a>, sanitation, clothing, shelter, health care and education. Relative poverty is defined contextually as <a href="/wiki/Economic_inequality" title="Economic inequality">economic inequality</a> in the location or society in which people live.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Industrial_revolution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Industrial revolution (page does not exist)">industrial revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mass_production" title="Mass production">mass production</a> in factories made production goods increasingly less expensive and more accessible.  Of more importance is the modernization of <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_agriculture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of agriculture (page does not exist)">agriculture</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Fertilizer" title="Fertilizer">fertilizers</a>, to provide enough yield to feed the population.<sup id="cite_ref-Obama_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Obama-4">[4]</a></sup> The supply of basic needs can be restricted by constraints on government services such as corruption, <a href="/wiki/Tax_avoidance" title="Tax avoidance">tax avoidance</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Developing_countries%27_debt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Developing countries' debt (page does not exist)">debt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Conditionality" title="Conditionality">loan conditionalities</a> and by the <a href="/wiki/Brain_drain" title="Brain drain">brain drain</a> of health care and educational professionals. Strategies of increasing income to make basic needs more affordable typically include welfare, economic freedoms, and providing financial services.
</p><p><a href="#Poverty_reduction">Poverty reduction</a> is a major goal and issue for many international organizations such as the United Nations and the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>. The World Bank estimated 1.29 billion people were living in absolute poverty in 2008. Of these, about 400 million people in absolute poverty lived in India and 173 million people in China. In terms of percentage of regional populations, <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_Africa" title="Poverty in Africa">sub-Saharan Africa</a> at 47% had the highest incidence rate of absolute poverty in 2008. Between 1990 and 2010, about 663 million people moved above the absolute poverty level. Still, extreme poverty is a global challenge; it is observed in all parts of the world, including developed economies.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</li>
</ul>
</li>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>The word poverty comes from old French poverté (Modern French: pauvreté), from Latin paupertās, from pauper (poor).<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>The English word "poverty" via <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anglo-Norman_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anglo-Norman language (page does not exist)">Anglo-Norman</a> povert.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} There are several definitions of poverty depending on the context of the situation it is placed in, and the views of the person giving the definition.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Measuring_poverty">Measuring poverty</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Definitions">Definitions</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Percentage_population_living_on_less_than_1_dollar_day_2007-2008.png" title="File:Percentage population living on less than 1 dollar day 2007-2008.png">File:Percentage population living on less than 1 dollar day 2007-2008.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Percentage of population living on less than $1.25 per day, 2009.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Percentage_population_undernourished_world_map.PNG" title="File:Percentage population undernourished world map.PNG">File:Percentage population undernourished world map.PNG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Percentage of population suffering from hunger, <a href="/wiki/World_Food_Programme" title="World Food Programme">World Food Programme</a>, 2008</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Life_Expectancy_2008_Estimates_CIA_World_Factbook.png" title="File:Life Expectancy 2008 Estimates CIA World Factbook.png">File:Life Expectancy 2008 Estimates CIA World Factbook.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">Life expectancy</a>, 2008.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2011_UN_Human_Development_Report_Quartiles.svg" title="File:2011 UN Human Development Report Quartiles.svg">File:2011 UN Human Development Report Quartiles.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>, 2006</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gini_Coefficient_World_CIA_Report_2009.png" title="File:Gini Coefficient World CIA Report 2009.png">File:Gini Coefficient World CIA Report 2009.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Gini_coefficient" title="Gini coefficient">Gini coefficient</a>, a measure of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Income_inequality&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Income inequality (page does not exist)">income inequality</a>, 2009.</div></div></div>
<p>United Nations: Fundamentally, poverty is the inability of getting choices and opportunities, a violation of human dignity. It means lack of basic capacity to participate effectively in society. It means not having enough to feed and clothe a family, not having a school or clinic to go to, not having the land on which to grow one’s food or a job to earn one’s living, not having access to credit. It means insecurity, powerlessness and exclusion of individuals, households and communities. It means susceptibility to violence, and it often implies living in marginal or fragile environments, without access to clean water or sanitation.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>: Poverty is pronounced deprivation in well-being, and comprises many dimensions. It includes low incomes and the inability to acquire the basic goods and services necessary for survival with dignity. Poverty also encompasses low levels of health and education, poor access to clean water and sanitation, inadequate physical security, lack of voice, and insufficient capacity and opportunity to better one’s life.
<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p><p>Copenhagen Declaration: <i>Absolute poverty</i> is a condition characterized by severe deprivation of basic human needs, including food, safe drinking water, sanitation facilities, health, shelter, education and information.  It depends not only on income but also on access to social services.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> The term 'absolute poverty' is sometimes synonymously referred to as 'extreme poverty.'<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>Poverty is usually measured as either <a href="/wiki/Absolute_poverty" title="Absolute poverty" class="mw-redirect">absolute</a> or <a href="/wiki/Poverty#Relative_poverty" title="Poverty">relative</a> (the latter being actually an index of income inequality).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Absolute_poverty">Absolute poverty</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Absolute poverty refers to a set standard which is consistent over time and between countries. First introduced in 1990, the dollar a day <a href="/wiki/Poverty_threshold" title="Poverty threshold">poverty line</a> measured absolute poverty by the standards of the world’s poorest countries. <a href="/wiki/The_World_Bank" title="The World Bank" class="mw-redirect">The World Bank</a> defined the new international poverty line as $1.25 a day for 2005 (equivalent to $1.00 a day in 1996 US prices).<sup id="cite_ref-dollarrevisited2008_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dollarrevisited2008-12">[12]</a></sup> but have recently been updated to be $1.25 and $2.50 per day.<sup id="cite_ref-RavaillionWB26Jun2009_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RavaillionWB26Jun2009-13">[13]</a></sup> Absolute poverty, <a href="/wiki/Extreme_poverty" title="Extreme poverty">extreme poverty</a>, or abject poverty is "a condition characterized by severe deprivation of basic human needs, including food, safe drinking water, sanitation facilities, health, shelter, education and information. It depends not only on income but also on access to services." <sup id="cite_ref-UN1995_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN1995-14">[14]</a></sup> The term 'absolute poverty', when used in this fashion, is usually synonymous with 'extreme poverty': <a href="/wiki/Robert_McNamara" title="Robert McNamara">Robert McNamara</a>, the former President of the World Bank, described absolute or extreme poverty as, "...a condition so limited by <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a>, <a href="/wiki/Illiteracy" title="Illiteracy" class="mw-redirect">illiteracy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Disease" title="Disease">disease</a>, squalid surroundings, high <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality</a>, and low <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> as to be beneath any reasonable definition of human decency".<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[notes 1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SachsEndofPoverty2005_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SachsEndofPoverty2005-17">[16]</a></sup> Australia is one of the world's wealthier nations. In his article published in Australian Policy Online, Robert Tanton notes that, "While this amount is appropriate for third world countries, in Australia, the amount required to meet these basic needs will naturally be much higher because prices of these basic necessities are higher."
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Percentage_population_living_on_less_than_1_dollar_day_2007-2008.png" title="File:Percentage population living on less than 1 dollar day 2007-2008.png">File:Percentage population living on less than 1 dollar day 2007-2008.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Map of world poverty by country, showing percentage of population living on less than $1.25 per day. Australia ranks very high with many OECD countries.</div></div></div>
<p>However as the amount of wealth required for survival is not the same in all places and time periods, particularly in highly developed countries where few people would fall below the World Bank's poverty lines, countries often develop their own National poverty lines.
</p><p>An absolute poverty line was calculated in Australia for the Henderson poverty inquiry in 1973. It was $62.70 a week, which was the disposable income required to support the basic needs of a family of two adults and two dependent children at the time. This poverty line has been updated regularly by the Melbourne Institute according to increases in average incomes; for a single employed person it was $391.85 per week (including housing costs) in March 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-povertyinequality_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-povertyinequality-18">[17]</a></sup> In Australia the OECD poverty would equate to a "disposable income of less than $358 per week for a single adult (higher for larger households to take account of their greater costs).<sup id="cite_ref-PovertyAustraliaACOSS2012_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PovertyAustraliaACOSS2012-19">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>For a few years starting 1990, The World Bank anchored absolute poverty line as $1 per day. This was revised in 1993, and through 2005, absolute poverty was $1.08 a day for all countries on a <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> basis, after adjusting for inflation to the 1993 U.S. dollar. In 2005, after extensive studies of cost of living across the world, The World Bank raised the measure for global poverty line to reflect the observed higher cost of living.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[19]</a></sup> Now, the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_Group" title="World Bank Group">World Bank</a> defines <a href="/wiki/Extreme_poverty" title="Extreme poverty">extreme poverty</a> as living on less than US$1.25 (<a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>) per day, and <i>moderate poverty</i>{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} as less than $2 or $5 a day (but note that a person or family with access to subsistence resources, e.g. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Subsistence_farmers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Subsistence farmers (page does not exist)">subsistence farmers</a>, may have a low cash income without a correspondingly low standard of living – they are not living "on" their cash income but using it as a top up). It estimates that "in 2001, 1.1 billion people had consumption levels below $1 a day and 2.7 billion lived on less than $2 a day."<sup id="cite_ref-worldbank-Poverty_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank-Poverty-21">[20]</a></sup> A <i>dollar a day</i>, in nations that do not use the U.S. dollar as currency, does not translate to living a day on the equivalent amount of local currency as determined by the <a href="/wiki/Exchange_rate" title="Exchange rate">exchange rate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-dollar_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dollar-22">[21]</a></sup> Rather, it is determined by the <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> rate, which would look at how much local currency is needed to buy the same things that a dollar could buy in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-dollar_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dollar-22">[21]</a></sup> Usually, this would translate to less local currency than the exchange rate in poorer countries as the United States is a relatively more expensive country.<sup id="cite_ref-dollar_22-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dollar-22">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>The poverty line threshold of $1.25 per day, as set by The World Bank, is controversial. Each nation has its own threshold for absolute poverty line; in the United States, for example, the absolute poverty line was US$15.15 per day in 2010 (US$22,000 per year for a family of four),<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[22]</a></sup> while in India it was US$ 1.0 per day<sup id="cite_ref-wb2010a_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wb2010a-24">[23]</a></sup> and in China the absolute poverty line was US$ 0.55 per day, each on PPP basis in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[24]</a></sup> These different poverty lines make data comparison between each nation's official reports qualitatively difficult. Some scholars argue that The World Bank method sets the bar too high, others argue it is low. Still others suggest that poverty line misleads as it measures everyone below the poverty line the same, when in reality someone living on $1.2 per day is in a different state of poverty than someone living on $0.2 per day. In other words, the depth and intensity of poverty varies across the world and in any regional populations, and $1.25 per day poverty line and head counts are inadequate measures.<sup id="cite_ref-wb2010a_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wb2010a-24">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>The proportion of the <a href="/wiki/Developing_world" title="Developing world" class="mw-redirect">developing world</a>'s population living in extreme economic poverty fell from 28 percent in 1990 to 21 percent in 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-worldbank-Poverty_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank-Poverty-21">[20]</a></sup> Most of this improvement has occurred in <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Asia (page does not exist)">East</a> and South Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-1980s_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1980s-28">[27]</a></sup> In East Asia the World Bank reported that "The poverty headcount rate at the $2-a-day level is estimated to have fallen to about 27 percent [in 2007], down from 29.5 percent in 2006 and 69 percent in 1990."<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[28]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan Africa</a> extreme poverty went up from 41 percent in 1981 to 46 percent in 2001,<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[29]</a></sup> which combined with growing population increased the number of people living in extreme poverty from 231 million to 318 million.<sup id="cite_ref-birthrates_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-birthrates-31">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early 1990s some of the transition economies of Central and Eastern Europe and Central Asia experienced a sharp drop in income.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[31]</a></sup> The collapse of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> resulted in large declines in GDP per capita, of about 30 to 35% between 1990 and the trough year of 1998 (when it was at its minimum). As a result poverty rates also increased although in subsequent years as per capita incomes recovered the poverty rate dropped from 31.4% of the population to 19.6%.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Soviet_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Soviet-34">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>World Bank data shows that the percentage of the population living in households with consumption or income per person below the poverty line has decreased in each region of the world since 1990:<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[35]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable">


<tr>
<th rowspan="2"><b>Region</b>
</th>
<th colspan="3"> $1 per day
</th>
<th rowspan="2">

</th></tr>

</td></tr>

</td>

</td>

</td>

</td>
<td> 0.5%
</td></tr>
<tr>

</td>

</td>

</td>

</td></tr>

</td></tr>

</td>

</td>

</td></tr>

</td>

</td>

</td>

</td>
<td> 51.5%
</td>
<td> 47.5%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th> World

</th>
