</th>
<th> 52.2%
</th>
<th> 22.4%
</th></tr></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Life_expectancy_1950-2005.png" title="File:Life expectancy 1950-2005.png">File:Life expectancy 1950-2005.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Life expectancy has been increasing and converging for most of the world. Sub-Saharan Africa has recently seen a decline, partly related to the <a href="/wiki/AIDS_epidemic" title="AIDS epidemic" class="mw-redirect">AIDS epidemic</a>. Graph shows the years 1950–2005.</div></div></div>
<p>According to Chen and Ravallion, about 1.76 billion people in developing world lived <i>above</i> $1.25 per day and 1.9 billion people lived <i>below</i> $1.25 per day in 1981. The world's population increased over the next 25 years. In 2005, about 4.09 billion people in developing world lived above $1.25 per day and 1.4 billion people lived below $1.25 per day (both 1981 and 2005 data are on inflation adjusted basis).<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[38]</a></sup> Some scholars caution that these trends are subject to various assumptions, and not certain. Additionally, they note that the poverty reduction is not uniform across the world; economically prospering countries such as China, India and Brazil have made more progress in absolute poverty reduction than countries in other regions of the world.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>The absolute poverty measure trends noted above are supported by human development indicators, which have also been improving. <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">Life expectancy</a> has greatly increased in the developing world since World War II and is starting to close the gap to the developed world.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} <a href="/w/index.php?title=Child_mortality&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Child mortality (page does not exist)">Child mortality</a> has decreased in every developing region of the world.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[40]</a></sup> The proportion of the world's population living in countries where per-capita food supplies are less than 2,200 calories (9,200 <a href="/wiki/Kilojoule" title="Kilojoule" class="mw-redirect">kilojoules</a>) per day decreased from 56% in the mid-1960s to below 10% by the 1990s. Similar trends can be observed for literacy, access to clean water and electricity and basic consumer items.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[41]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Relative_poverty">Relative poverty</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Extreme_poverty_1981%E2%80%932008.png" title="File:Extreme poverty 1981–2008.png">File:Extreme poverty 1981–2008.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">This graph shows the proportion of world population in <a href="/wiki/Extreme_poverty" title="Extreme poverty">extreme poverty</a> 1981–2008 according to the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Relative poverty views poverty as socially defined and dependent on <a href="/wiki/Social_context" title="Social context" class="mw-redirect">social context</a>, hence relative poverty is a measure of income inequality. Usually, relative poverty is measured as the percentage of population with income less than some fixed proportion of median income. There are several other different <a href="/wiki/Income_inequality_metrics" title="Income inequality metrics">income inequality metrics</a>, for example the <a href="/wiki/Gini_coefficient" title="Gini coefficient">Gini coefficient</a> or the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Theil_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Theil Index (page does not exist)">Theil Index</a>.
</p><p>Relative poverty is the "most useful measure for ascertaining poverty rates in wealthy developed nations."<sup id="cite_ref-Raphael2009_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Raphael2009-43">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Innocenti2005_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Innocenti2005-44">[43]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-OECD2008_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD2008-45">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UNDP2008_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNDP2008-46">[45]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ConferenceBoard2013_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ConferenceBoard2013-47">[46]</a></sup> Relative poverty measure is used by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_Nations_Development_Program&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United Nations Development Program (page does not exist)">United Nations Development Program</a> (UNDP), the <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNICEF&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNICEF (page does not exist)">United Nations Children’s Fund</a> (UNICEF), the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (page does not exist)">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD) and Canadian poverty researchers.<sup id="cite_ref-Raphael2009_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Raphael2009-43">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Innocenti2005_44-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Innocenti2005-44">[43]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-OECD2008_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD2008-45">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UNDP2008_46-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNDP2008-46">[45]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ConferenceBoard2013_47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ConferenceBoard2013-47">[46]</a></sup> In the European Union, the "relative poverty measure is the most prominent and most–quoted of the EU social inclusion indicators."<sup id="cite_ref-povinequalityCSP_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-povinequalityCSP-48">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>"Relative poverty reflects better the cost of social inclusion and equality of opportunity in a specific time and space."<sup id="cite_ref-relativeBradshawInnocenti2012_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-relativeBradshawInnocenti2012-49">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>"Once economic development has progressed beyond a certain minimum level, the rub of the poverty problem – from the point of view of both the poor individual and of the societies in which they live – is not so much the effects of poverty in any absolute form but the effects of the contrast, daily perceived, between the lives of the poor and the lives of those around them. For practical purposes, the problem of poverty in the industrialized nations today is a problem of relative poverty (page 9)."<sup id="cite_ref-relativeBradshawInnocenti2012_49-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-relativeBradshawInnocenti2012-49">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UNICEF2000_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNICEF2000-50">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1776 Adam Smith in the Wealth of Nations argued that poverty is the inability to afford, "not only the commodities which are indispensably necessary for the support of life, but whatever the custom of the country renders it indecent for creditable people, even of the lowest order, to be without."<sup id="cite_ref-AdamSmith1776_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AdamSmith1776-51">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Innocenti2012_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Innocenti2012-52">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1958 <a href="/wiki/John_Kenneth_Galbraith" title="John Kenneth Galbraith">J. K. Galbraith</a> argued that, "People are poverty stricken when their income, even if adequate for survival, falls markedly behind that of their community."<sup id="cite_ref-Innocenti2012_52-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Innocenti2012-52">[51]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Galbraith1958_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Galbraith1958-53">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1964 in a joint committee economic President's report in the United States, Republicans endorsed the concept of relative poverty. ”No objective definition of poverty exists... The definition varies from place to place and time to time. In America as our standard of living rises, so does our idea of what is substandard."<sup id="cite_ref-Innocenti2012_52-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Innocenti2012-52">[51]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-rep1964_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rep1964-54">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:DorotheaLangeMigrantWorkersChildren.jpg" title="File:DorotheaLangeMigrantWorkersChildren.jpg">File:DorotheaLangeMigrantWorkersChildren.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Children of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Depression&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Depression (page does not exist)">Depression</a>-era migrant workers, Arizona, 1937</div></div></div>
<p>In 1965 <a href="/wiki/Rose_Friedman" title="Rose Friedman">Rose Friedman</a> argued for the use of relative poverty claiming that the definition of poverty changes with general living standards. Those labelled as poor in 1995, would have had "a higher standard of living than many labelled not poor" in 1965.<sup id="cite_ref-Innocenti2012_52-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Innocenti2012-52">[51]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Friedman1965_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Friedman1965-55">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1979, British sociologist, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Townsend_(sociologist)" title="Peter Townsend (sociologist)">Peter Townsend</a> published his famous definition, "individuals [...] can be said to be in poverty when they lack the resources to obtain the types of diet, participate in the activities and have the living conditions and amenities which are customary, or are at least widely encouraged or approved, in the societies to which they belong (page 31)."<sup id="cite_ref-Townsend1979_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Townsend1979-56">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>Brian Nolan and Christopher T. Whelan of the Economic and Social Research Institute (ESRI) in Ireland explained that, "[P]overty has to be seen in terms of the standard of living of the society in question."<sup id="cite_ref-CallanNolan1993_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CallanNolan1993-57">[56]</a></sup>
</p><p>Relative poverty measures are used as official poverty rates by the European Union, UNICEF and the OEDC. The main poverty line used in the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD" class="mw-redirect">OECD</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> is based on "economic distance", a level of income set at 60% of the median household income.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[57]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_aspects">Other aspects</span></h3>
<p>Economic aspects of poverty focus on material needs, typically including the necessities of daily living, such as food, clothing, shelter, or safe drinking water. Poverty in this sense may be understood as a condition in which a person or community is lacking in the basic needs for a minimum standard of well-being and life, particularly as a result of a persistent lack of income.
</p><p>Analysis of social aspects of poverty links conditions of scarcity to aspects of the distribution of resources and power in a society and recognizes that poverty may be a function of the diminished "capability" of people to live the kinds of lives they value. The social aspects of poverty may include lack of <a href="/wiki/Information_access" title="Information access">access to information</a>, education, health care, or political power.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p>Poverty levels are snapshot picture in time that omits the transitional dynamics between levels. Mobility statistics supply additional information about the fraction who leave the poverty level. For example, one study finds that in a sixteen-year period (1975 to 1991 in the U.S.) only 5% of those in the lower fifth of the income level were still in that level, while 95% transitioned to a higher income category.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[60]</a></sup> Poverty levels can remain the same while those who rise out of poverty are replaced by others. The transient poor and chronic poor differ in each society. In a nine-year period ending in 2005 for the U.S., 50% of the poorest quintile transitioned to a higher quintile.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>Poverty may also be understood as an aspect of unequal <a href="/wiki/Social_status" title="Social status">social status</a> and inequitable social relationships, experienced as social exclusion, dependency, and diminished capacity to participate, or to develop meaningful connections with other people in society.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[64]</a></sup> Such social exclusion can be minimized through strengthened connections with the mainstream, such as through the provision of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Relational_care&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Relational care (page does not exist)">relational care</a> to those who are experiencing poverty.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tiggare_vid_Operak%C3%A4llaren.jpg" title="File:Tiggare vid Operakällaren.jpg">File:Tiggare vid Operakällaren.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">An early morning outside the Opera Tavern in Stockholm, with a gang of beggars waiting for delivery of the scraps from the previous day. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden (page does not exist)">Sweden</a>, 1868.</div></div></div>
<p>The World Bank's "Voices of the Poor," based on research with over 20,000 poor people in 23 countries, identifies a range of factors which poor people identify as part of poverty. These include:
</p>
<ul>
<li> Abuse by those in power
</li>
<li> Dis-empowering institutions
</li>
<li> Excluded locations
</li>
<li> Gender relationships
</li>
<li> Lack of security
</li>
<li> Limited capabilities
</li>
<li> Physical limitations
</li>
<li> Precarious livelihoods
</li>
<li> Problems in social relationships
</li>
<li> Weak community organizations
</li>
</ul>
<p>David Moore, in his book <i>The World Bank</i>, argues that some analysis of poverty reflect pejorative, sometimes racial, stereotypes of impoverished people as powerless victims and passive recipients of aid programs.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ultra-poverty, a term apparently coined by Michael Lipton,<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[66]</a></sup> connotes being amongst poorest of the poor in low-income countries. Lipton defined ultra-poverty as receiving less than 80 percent of minimum caloric intake whilst spending more than 80% of income on food. Alternatively a 2007 report issued by International Food Policy Research Institute defined ultra-poverty as living on less than 54 cents per day.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Asset_poverty&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asset poverty (page does not exist)">Asset poverty</a> is an economic and social condition that is more persistent and prevalent than income poverty.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[68]</a></sup> It can be defined as a household’s inability to access wealth resources that are sufficient enough to provide for basic needs for a period of three months. Basic needs refer to the minimum standards for consumption and acceptable needs.[1] Wealth resources consist of home ownership, other real estate (second home, rented properties, etc.), net value of farm and business assets, stocks, checking and savings accounts, and other savings (money in savings bonds, life insurance policy cash values, etc.).[2] Wealth is measured in three forms: net worth, net worth minus home equity, and liquid assets. Net worth consists of all the aspects mentioned above. Net worth minus home equity is the same except it does not include home ownership in asset calculations. Liquid assets are resources that are readily available such as cash, checking and savings accounts, stocks, and other sources of savings.[2] There are two types of assets: tangible and intangible. Tangible assets most closely resemble liquid assets in that they include stocks, bonds, property, natural resources, and hard assets not in the form of real estate. Intangible assets are simply the access to credit, social capital, cultural capital, political capital, and human capital.[3]
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Characteristics">Characteristics</span></h2>
<p>The effects of poverty may also be causes, as listed above, thus creating a "poverty cycle" operating across multiple levels, individual, local, national and global.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Disputed-section&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Disputed-section (page does not exist)">Template:Disputed-section</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:VOA_Heinlein_-_Somali_refugees_September_2011_-_09.jpg" title="File:VOA Heinlein - Somali refugees September 2011 - 09.jpg">File:VOA Heinlein - Somali refugees September 2011 - 09.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Diplomatic_and_humanitarian_efforts_in_the_Somali_Civil_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diplomatic and humanitarian efforts in the Somali Civil War (page does not exist)">Somali</a> boy receiving treatment for malnourishment at a health facility.</div></div></div>
<p>One third of deaths – some 18 million people a year or 50,000 per day – are due to poverty-related causes: in total 270 million people, most of them women and children, have died as a result of poverty since 1990.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[69]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Failed_verification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Failed verification (page does not exist)">Template:Failed verification</a> Those living in poverty suffer disproportionately from hunger or even <a href="/wiki/Starvation" title="Starvation">starvation</a> and disease.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[70]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Failed_verification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Failed verification (page does not exist)">Template:Failed verification</a>
Those living in poverty suffer lower <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a>. According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hunger" title="Hunger">hunger</a> and <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a> are the single gravest threats to the world's public health and malnutrition is by far the biggest contributor to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Child_mortality&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Child mortality (page does not exist)">child mortality</a>, present in half of all cases.<sup id="cite_ref-economist_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economist-72">[71]</a></sup> Almost 90% of <a href="/wiki/Maternal_death" title="Maternal death">maternal deaths</a> during childbirth occur in Asia and sub-Saharan Africa, compared to less than 1% in the developed world.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[72]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Relevance-inline&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Relevance-inline (page does not exist)">Template:Relevance-inline</a>
</p><p>Those who live in poverty have also been shown to have a far greater likelihood of having or incurring a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Disability_and_Poverty&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Disability and Poverty (page does not exist)">disability</a> within their lifetime.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[73]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Infectious_diseases" title="Infectious diseases" class="mw-redirect">Infectious diseases</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Malaria" title="Malaria">malaria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tuberculosis" title="Tuberculosis">tuberculosis</a> can perpetuate poverty by diverting health and economic resources from investment and productivity; malaria decreases GDP growth by up to 1.3% in some developing nations and AIDS decreases African growth by 0.3–1.5% annually.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[74]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[75]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>A pair of studies of the influence of poverty on the ability to reason about complicated issues requiring an immediate solution found that poverty directly impedes cognitive function. Financial worries appear to put a severe burden on one's mental resources so that they are no longer fully available for solving complicated problems. The reduced capability for problem solving can lead to suboptimal decisions and further perpetuate poverty.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[77]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hunger">Hunger</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Poor_woman_in_Parambikkulam,_India.jpg" title="File:Poor woman in Parambikkulam, India.jpg">File:Poor woman in Parambikkulam, India.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A reality of poverty</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Payatas-Dumpsite_Manila_Philippines02.jpg" title="File:Payatas-Dumpsite Manila Philippines02.jpg">File:Payatas-Dumpsite Manila Philippines02.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">People who earn their living by collecting and sorting garbage and selling them for recycling, Payatas, <a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Rises in the costs of living making poor people less able to afford items. Poor people spend a <a href="/wiki/Engel%27s_law" title="Engel's law">greater portion of their budgets</a> on food than richer people. As a result, poor households and those near the poverty threshold can be particularly vulnerable to increases in <a href="/wiki/Food#Prices" title="Food">food prices</a>. For example, in late 2007 increases in the price of grains<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[78]</a></sup> led to <a href="/w/index.php?title=2007%E2%80%932008_world_food_price_crisis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2007–2008 world food price crisis (page does not exist)">food riots</a> in some countries.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[79]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[81]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> warned that 100 million people were at risk of sinking deeper into poverty.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[82]</a></sup> Threats to the supply of food may also be caused by drought and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Water_crisis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Water crisis (page does not exist)">water crisis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[83]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Intensive_farming" title="Intensive farming">Intensive farming</a> often leads to a vicious cycle of exhaustion of <a href="/wiki/Erosion" title="Erosion">soil fertility</a> and decline of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agricultural_yields&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agricultural yields (page does not exist)">agricultural yields</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[84]</a></sup> Approximately 40% of the world's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agricultural_land&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agricultural land (page does not exist)">agricultural land</a> is seriously degraded.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[86]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_Africa" title="Poverty in Africa">Africa</a>, if current trends of <a href="/wiki/Soil_degradation" title="Soil degradation" class="mw-redirect">soil degradation</a> continue, the continent might be able to feed just 25% of its population by 2025, according to <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_University" title="United Nations University">United Nations University</a>'s Ghana-based Institute for Natural Resources in Africa.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[87]</a></sup> Every year nearly 11 million children living in poverty die before their fifth birthday. 1.02 billion people go to bed hungry every night.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_Hunger_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global Hunger Index (page does not exist)">Global Hunger Index</a>, Sub-Saharan Africa had the highest child malnutrition rate of the world's regions over the 2001-2006 period.<sup id="cite_ref-ghi2008_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ghi2008-90">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Research has found that there is a high risk of educational underachievement for children who are from low-income housing circumstances. This is often a process that begins in primary school for some less fortunate children. Instruction in the US educational system, as well as in most other countries, tends to be geared towards those students who come from more advantaged backgrounds. As a result, children in poverty are at a higher risk than advantaged children for retention in their grade, special deleterious placements during the school's hours and even not completing their high school education.<sup id="cite_ref-SYF_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SYF-91">[90]</a></sup> There are indeed many explanations for why students tend to drop out of school. One is the conditions of which they attend school. Schools in poverty-stricken areas have conditions that hinder children from learning in a safe environment. Researchers have developed a name for areas like this: an urban war zone is a poor, crime-laden district in which deteriorated, violent, even war-like conditions and underfunded, largely ineffective schools promote inferior academic performance, including irregular attendance and disruptive or non-compliant classroom behavior.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[91]</a></sup> For children with low resources, the risk factors are similar to others such as <a href="/wiki/Juvenile_delinquency" title="Juvenile delinquency">juvenile delinquency</a> rates, higher levels of <a href="/wiki/Teenage_pregnancy" title="Teenage pregnancy">teenage pregnancy</a>, and the economic dependency upon their low income parent or parents.<sup id="cite_ref-SYF_91-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SYF-91">[90]</a></sup>
Families and society who submit low levels of investment in the education and development of less fortunate children end up with less favorable results for the children who see a life of parental employment reduction and low wages. Higher rates of early <a href="/wiki/Pregnancy" title="Pregnancy">childbearing</a> with all the connected risks to family, health and well-being are major important issues to address since education from preschool to high school are both identifiably meaningful in a life.<sup id="cite_ref-SYF_91-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SYF-91">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>Poverty often drastically affects children's success in school. A child's "home activities, preferences, mannerisms" must align with the world and in the cases that they do not these students are at a disadvantage in the school and most importantly the classroom.<sup id="cite_ref-ANF_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ANF-93">[92]</a></sup> Therefore, it is safe to state that children who live at or below the poverty level will have far less success educationally than children who live above the poverty line. Poor children have a great deal less healthcare and this ultimately results in many absences from the academic year. Additionally, poor children are much more likely to suffer from hunger, fatigue, irritability, headaches, ear infections, flu, and colds.<sup id="cite_ref-ANF_93-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ANF-93">[92]</a></sup> These illnesses could potentially restrict a child or student's focus and concentration.
</p><p><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[93]</a></sup> for a child to grow up emotionally healthy children under three need “A strong, reliable primary caregiver who provides consistent and unconditional love, guidance, and support. Safe, predictable, stable environments. Ten to 20 hours each week of harmonious, reciprocal interactions. This process, known as attunement, is most crucial during the first 6–24 months of infants' lives and helps them develop a wider range of healthy emotions, including gratitude, forgiveness, and empathy. Enrichment through personalized, increasingly complex activities”
</p><p>Harmful spending habits mean that the poor typically spend about 2 percent of their income educating their children but larger percentages on alcohol and tobacco (For example, 6 percent in Indonesia and 8 percent in Mexico).<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Housing">Housing</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Street_Child,_Srimangal_Railway_Station.jpg" title="File:Street Child, Srimangal Railway Station.jpg">File:Street Child, Srimangal Railway Station.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Street child in <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Homeless_children_in_US_2006-10.png" title="File:Homeless children in US 2006-10.png">File:Homeless children in US 2006-10.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Homeless children in the US grew from 1.2 million in 2007 to 1.6 million in 2010. The United States defines homelessness per <a href="/w/index.php?title=McKinney%E2%80%93Vento_Homeless_Assistance_Act&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="McKinney–Vento Homeless Assistance Act (page does not exist)">McKinney–Vento Homeless Assistance Act</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[95]</a></sup> The number of homeless children reached record highs in 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[96]</a></sup> 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-coalition4homeless_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-coalition4homeless-98">[97]</a></sup> and 2013<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[98]</a></sup> at about three times their number in 1983.<sup id="cite_ref-coalition4homeless_98-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-coalition4homeless-98">[97]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Poverty increases the risk of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Homelessness&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Homelessness (page does not exist)">homelessness</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[99]</a></sup> Slum-dwellers, who make up a third of the world's urban population, live in a poverty no better, if not worse, than rural people, who are the traditional focus of the poverty in the <a href="/wiki/Developing_world" title="Developing world" class="mw-redirect">developing world</a>, according to a report by the United Nations.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are over 100 million <a href="/wiki/Street_children" title="Street children">street children</a> worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[101]</a></sup> Most of the children living in institutions around the world have a surviving parent or close relative, and they most commonly entered orphanages because of poverty.<sup id="cite_ref-orphanages_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-orphanages-103">[102]</a></sup> Experts and child advocates maintain that orphanages are expensive and often harm children's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Child_development&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Child development (page does not exist)">development</a> by separating them from their families.<sup id="cite_ref-orphanages_103-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-orphanages-103">[102]</a></sup> It is speculated that, flush with money, orphanages are increasing and push for children to join even though demographic data show that even the poorest extended families usually take in children whose parents have died.<sup id="cite_ref-orphanages_103-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-orphanages-103">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Utilities">Utilities</span></h3>
<p>Water utility subsidies tend to subsidize water consumption by those connected to the network, which typically includes the richer segment of the population. As a result, the price of water decreases to the extent that only 30%, on average, of the supplying costs in developing countries is covered.<sup id="cite_ref-utilitysubsidy_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-utilitysubsidy-104">[103]</a></sup>
This results in a lack of incentive to maintain delivery systems, leading to losses from leaks annually that is enough for 200 million people.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[104]</a></sup>
This also leads to a lack of incentive to invest in expanding the network, resulting in much of the poor population being unconnected to the network. Instead, the poor buy water from water vendors for, on average, about five to 16 times the metered price.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[105]</a></sup> However, subsidies for laying new connections to the network rather than for consumption has shown more promise for the poor.<sup id="cite_ref-utilitysubsidy_104-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-utilitysubsidy-104">[103]</a></sup>
</p><p>Similarly, the poorest fifth receive 0.1% of the world’s lighting but pay a fifth of total spending on light, accounting for 25 to 30 percent of their income.<sup id="cite_ref-solar_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-solar-107">[106]</a></sup> Indoor air pollution from burning fuels kills 2 million, with almost half the deaths from pneumonia in children under 5.<sup id="cite_ref-bamboo_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bamboo-108">[107]</a></sup> Fuel from Bamboo burns more cleanly and also matures much faster than wood, thus also reducing deforestation.<sup id="cite_ref-bamboo_108-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bamboo-108">[107]</a></sup> Additionally, using solar panels is promoted as being cheaper over the products' lifetime even if upfront costs are higher.<sup id="cite_ref-solar_107-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-solar-107">[106]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Violence">Violence</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>According to experts, many women become victims of trafficking, the most common form of which is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Survival_sex&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Survival sex (page does not exist)">prostitution</a>, as a means of survival and economic desperation.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[108]</a></sup> Deterioration of living conditions can often compel children to abandon school to contribute to the family income, putting them at risk of  being exploited.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[109]</a></sup> For example, in <a href="/wiki/Zimbabwe" title="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a>, a number of girls are turning to sex in return for food to survive because of the increasing poverty.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[110]</a></sup>
</p><p>In one survey, 67% of children from disadvantaged <a href="/wiki/Inner_city" title="Inner city">inner cities</a> said they had witnessed a serious assault, and 33% reported witnessing a homicide.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[111]</a></sup> 51% of fifth graders from <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans" title="New Orleans">New Orleans</a> (median income for a household: $27,133) have been found to be victims of violence, compared to 32% in Washington, DC (mean income for a household: $40,127).<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[112]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Poverty_reduction">Poverty reduction</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Various poverty reduction strategies are broadly categorized here based on whether they make more of the basic human needs available or increase the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Disposable_income&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Disposable income (page does not exist)">disposable income</a> needed to purchase those needs. Some strategies such as building roads can both bring access to various basic needs, such as fertilizer or healthcare from urban areas, as well as increase incomes, by bringing better access to urban markets.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Increasing_the_supply_of_basic_needs">Increasing the supply of basic needs</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Food_and_other_goods">Food and other goods</span></h4>
<p>Agricultural technologies such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nitrogen_fertilizer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nitrogen fertilizer (page does not exist)">nitrogen fertilizers</a>, pesticides and new irrigation methods have dramatically reduced food shortages in modern times by boosting yields past previous constraints.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[113]</a></sup>
</p><p>Before the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a>, poverty had been mostly accepted as inevitable as economies produced little, making wealth scarce.<sup id="cite_ref-britannica_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-115">[114]</a></sup> Geoffrey Parker wrote that "In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Antwerp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Antwerp (page does not exist)">Antwerp</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lyon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lyon (page does not exist)">Lyon</a>, two of the largest cities in <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">western Europe</a>, by 1600 three-quarters of the total population were too poor to pay taxes, and therefore likely to need relief in times of crisis."<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[115]</a></sup> The initial industrial revolution led to high economic growth and eliminated mass absolute poverty in what is now considered the developed world.<sup id="cite_ref-britannica_115-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-115">[114]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mass_production" title="Mass production">Mass production</a> of goods in places such as rapidly industrializing China has made what were once considered luxuries, such as vehicles and computers, inexpensive and thus accessible to many who were otherwise too poor to afford them.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[116]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p>Even with new products, such as better seeds, or greater volumes of them, such as industrial production, the poor still require access to these products. Improving <a href="/wiki/Road" title="Road">road</a> and transportation infrastructure helps solve this major bottleneck.  In Africa, it costs more to move fertilizer from an African seaport 60 miles inland than to ship it from the United States to Africa because of sparse, low quality roads, leading to fertilizer costs two to six times the world average.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[118]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microfranchising&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microfranchising (page does not exist)">Microfranchising</a> models such as door to door businesses are used to sell basic needs to remote areas for below market prices.<sup id="cite_ref-microfranchising_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-microfranchising-120">[119]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_care_and_education">Health care and education</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nigerian_Surgery_Table.jpg" title="File:Nigerian Surgery Table.jpg">File:Nigerian Surgery Table.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Hardwood surgical tables are commonplace in rural <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigerian</a> clinics.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Nations do not necessarily need wealth to gain health.<sup id="cite_ref-Disease_Control_Priorities_Project_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Disease_Control_Priorities_Project-121">[120]</a></sup> For example, <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a> had a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maternal_mortality_rate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maternal mortality rate (page does not exist)">maternal mortality rate</a> of 2% in the 1930s, higher than any nation today.<sup id="cite_ref-post_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-post-122">[121]</a></sup> It reduced it to 0.5–0.6% in the 1950s and to .06% today while spending less each year on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maternal_health&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maternal health (page does not exist)">maternal health</a> because it learned what worked and what did not.<sup id="cite_ref-post_122-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-post-122">[121]</a></sup> Cheap <a href="/wiki/Water_filter" title="Water filter">water filters</a> and promoting hand washing are some of the most cost effective health interventions and can cut <a href="/w/index.php?title=Child_mortality&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Child mortality (page does not exist)">deaths</a> from <a href="/wiki/Diarrhea" title="Diarrhea">diarrhea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pneumonia" title="Pneumonia">pneumonia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[122]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[123]</a></sup> Knowledge on the cost effectiveness of healthcare interventions can be elusive and educational measures have been made to disseminate what works, such as the <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Consensus" title="Copenhagen Consensus">Copenhagen Consensus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Disease_Control_Priorities_Project_121-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Disease_Control_Priorities_Project-121">[120]</a></sup>
</p><p>Strategies to provide education cost effectively include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Deworming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deworming (page does not exist)">deworming</a> children, which costs about 50 cents per child per year and reduces non-attendance from <a href="/wiki/Anemia" title="Anemia">anemia</a>, illness and malnutrition, while being only a twenty-fifth as expensive as increasing school attendance by constructing schools.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[124]</a></sup> Schoolgirl absenteeism could be cut in half by simply providing free <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sanitary_towel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sanitary towel (page does not exist)">sanitary towels</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p>Desirable actions such as enrolling children in school or receiving vaccinations can be encouraged by a form of aid known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Conditional_cash_transfer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Conditional cash transfer (page does not exist)">conditional cash transfers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Brazil_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brazil-127">[126]</a></sup> In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mexico&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mexico (page does not exist)">Mexico</a>, for example, dropout rates of 16- to 19-year-olds in rural area dropped by 20% and children gained half an inch in height.<sup id="cite_ref-csm_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-csm-128">[127]</a></sup> Initial fears that the program would encourage families to stay at home rather than work to collect benefits have proven to be unfounded. Instead, there is less excuse for neglectful behavior as, for example, children stopped begging on the streets instead of going to school because it could result in suspension from the program.<sup id="cite_ref-csm_128-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-csm-128">[127]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Removing_constraints_on_government_services">Removing constraints on government services</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Waiting_for_goods.JPG" title="File:Waiting for goods.JPG">File:Waiting for goods.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Local citizens from the Jana bi Village wait their turn to gather goods from the Sons of Iraq (Abna al-Iraq) in a military operation conducted in Yusufiyah, Iraq.</div></div></div>
<p>Government revenue can be diverted away from basic services by corruption.<sup id="cite_ref-unodc_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unodc-129">[128]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[129]</a></sup> Funds from aid and natural resources are often sent by government individuals for <a href="/wiki/Money_laundering" title="Money laundering">money laundering</a> to overseas banks which insist on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bank_secrecy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bank secrecy (page does not exist)">bank secrecy</a>, instead of spending on the poor.<sup id="cite_ref-graft_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-graft-131">[130]</a></sup> A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_Witness&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global Witness (page does not exist)">Global Witness</a> report asked for more action from Western banks as they have proved capable of stanching the flow of funds linked to terrorism.<sup id="cite_ref-graft_131-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-graft-131">[130]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Illicit_financial_flows&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Illicit financial flows (page does not exist)">Illicit capital flight</a> from the developing world is estimated at ten times the size of aid it receives and twice the debt service it pays.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[131]</a></sup> About 60 per cent of illicit capital flight from Africa is from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Transfer_mispricing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Transfer mispricing (page does not exist)">transfer mispricing</a>, where a <a href="/wiki/Subsidiary" title="Subsidiary">subsidiary</a> in a developing nation sells to another subsidiary or <a href="/wiki/Shell_company" title="Shell company" class="mw-redirect">shell company</a> in a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tax_haven&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tax haven (page does not exist)">tax haven</a> at an artificially low price to pay less tax.<sup id="cite_ref-transparency_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-transparency-133">[132]</a></sup> An <a href="/w/index.php?title=African_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="African Union (page does not exist)">African Union</a> report estimates that about 30% of sub-Saharan Africa's GDP has been moved to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tax_haven&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tax haven (page does not exist)">tax havens</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-guardian_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardian-134">[133]</a></sup> Solutions include corporate “country-by-country reporting” where corporations disclose activities in each country and thereby prohibit the use of tax havens where no effective economic activity occurs.<sup id="cite_ref-transparency_133-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-transparency-133">[132]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Developing_countries%27_debt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Developing countries' debt (page does not exist)">Developing countries' debt service</a> to banks and governments from richer countries can constrain government spending on the poor.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[134]</a></sup> For example, <a href="/wiki/Zambia" title="Zambia">Zambia</a> spent 40% of its total budget to repay foreign debt, and only 7% for basic state services in 1997.<sup id="cite_ref-worldcentric.org_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldcentric.org-136">[135]</a></sup> One of the proposed ways to help poor countries has been <a href="/wiki/Debt_relief" title="Debt relief">debt relief</a>. Zambia began offering services, such as free health care even while overwhelming the health care infrastructure, because of savings that resulted from a 2005 round of <a href="/wiki/Debt_relief" title="Debt relief">debt relief</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[136]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> and the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a>, as primary holders of developing countries' debt, attach <a href="/wiki/Structural_adjustment" title="Structural adjustment">structural adjustment</a> <a href="/wiki/Conditionality" title="Conditionality">conditionalities</a> in return for loans which generally include the elimination of state subsidies and the privatization of state services. For example, the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> presses poor nations to eliminate subsidies for fertilizer even while many farmers cannot afford them at market prices.<sup id="cite_ref-Malawi_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Malawi-138">[137]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Malawi" title="Malawi">Malawi</a>, almost five million of its 13 million people used to need emergency food aid but after the government changed policy and subsidies for fertilizer and seed were introduced, farmers produced record-breaking corn harvests in 2006 and 2007 as Malawi became a major food exporter.<sup id="cite_ref-Malawi_138-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Malawi-138">[137]</a></sup>
</p><p>A major proportion of aid from donor nations is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tied_aid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tied aid (page does not exist)">tied</a>, mandating that a receiving nation spend on products and expertise originating only from the donor country.
<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[138]</a></sup> US law requires <a href="/wiki/Food_aid" title="Food aid" class="mw-redirect">food aid</a> be spent on buying food at home, instead of where the hungry live, and, as a result, half of what is spent is used on transport.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[139]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Familiy_Planning_Ethiopia_(bad_effects).jpg" title="File:Familiy Planning Ethiopia (bad effects).jpg">File:Familiy Planning Ethiopia (bad effects).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/wiki/Family_planning" title="Family planning">family planning</a> placard in <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia" title="Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a>. It shows some negative effects of having too many children.</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Reversing_brain_drain">Reversing brain drain</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The loss of basic needs providers emigrating from impoverished countries has a damaging effect.<sup id="cite_ref-Philippines_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Philippines-141">[140]</a></sup> As of 2004, there were more Ethiopia-trained doctors living in Chicago than in Ethiopia.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[141]</a></sup> Proposals to mitigate the problem by the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> include compulsory government service for graduates of public medical and nursing schools and creating career-advancing programs to retain personnel.<sup id="cite_ref-Philippines_141-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Philippines-141">[140]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Controlling_overpopulation">Controlling overpopulation</span></h4>
<p>Some argue that overpopulation and lack of access to birth control leads to population increase to exceed food production and other resources.<sup id="cite_ref-birthrates_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-birthrates-31">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[142]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[143]</a></sup>  Better education for both men and women, and more control of their lives, reduces population growth due to <a href="/wiki/Family_planning" title="Family planning">family planning</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-empower_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-empower-145">[144]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Increasing_personal_income">Increasing personal income</span></h3>
<p>The following are strategies used or proposed to increase personal incomes among the poor. Raising farm incomes is described as the core of the antipoverty effort as three quarters of the poor today are farmers.<sup id="cite_ref-agriculture_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-agriculture-146">[145]</a></sup> Estimates show that growth in the agricultural productivity of small farmers is, on average, at least twice as effective in benefiting the poorest half of a country’s population as growth generated in nonagricultural sectors.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[146]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Income_grants">Income grants</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Afghan_girl_begging.jpg" title="File:Afghan girl begging.jpg">File:Afghan girl begging.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Afghan girl begging in <a href="/wiki/Kabul" title="Kabul">Kabul</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
A <a href="/wiki/Guaranteed_minimum_income" title="Guaranteed minimum income">guaranteed minimum income</a> ensures that every citizen will live be able to purchase a desired level of basic needs. A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Basic_income&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Basic income (page does not exist)">basic income</a> (or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Negative_income_tax&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Negative income tax (page does not exist)">negative income tax</a>) is a system of <a href="/wiki/Social_security" title="Social security">social security</a>, that periodically provides each citizen, rich or poor, with a sum of money that is <a href="/wiki/Sufficient" title="Sufficient" class="mw-redirect">sufficient</a> to live on. Studies of large cash-transfer programs in Ethiopia, Kenya, and Malawi show that the programs can be effective in increasing consumption, schooling, and nutrition, whether they are tied to such conditions or not.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[147]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Spiegel_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Spiegel-149">[148]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Namibians_line_up_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Namibians_line_up-150">[149]</a></sup> Proponents argue that a basic income is more economically efficient than a <a href="/wiki/Minimum_wage" title="Minimum wage">minimum wage</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Unemployment_benefit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unemployment benefit (page does not exist)">unemployment benefits</a>, as the minimum wage effectively imposes a high marginal tax on employers, causing <a href="/wiki/Deadweight_loss" title="Deadweight loss">losses in efficiency</a>. In 1968, <a href="/wiki/Paul_Samuelson" title="Paul Samuelson">Paul Samuelson</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Kenneth_Galbraith" title="John Kenneth Galbraith">John Kenneth Galbraith</a> and another 1,200 economists signed a document calling for the US Congress to introduce a system of income guarantees.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[150]</a></sup> Winners of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nobel_Prize_in_Economics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nobel Prize in Economics (page does not exist)">Nobel Prize in Economics</a>, with often diverse political convictions, who support a basic income include <a href="/wiki/Herbert_A._Simon" title="Herbert A. Simon">Herbert A. Simon</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Standing_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Standing-152">[151]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Hayek" title="Friedrich Hayek">Friedrich Hayek</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[152]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Robert_Solow" title="Robert Solow">Robert Solow</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Standing_152-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Standing-152">[151]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Milton_Friedman" title="Milton Friedman">Milton Friedman</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[153]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jan_Tinbergen" title="Jan Tinbergen">Jan Tinbergen</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Standing_152-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Standing-152">[151]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/James_Tobin" title="James Tobin">James Tobin</a><sup id="cite_ref-Steensland_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Steensland-155">[154]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[155]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[156]</a></sup>
and <a href="/wiki/James_Meade" title="James Meade">James Meade</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Standing_152-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Standing-152">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>Income grants are argued to be vastly more efficient in extending basic needs to the poor than <a href="/wiki/Subsidies" title="Subsidies" class="mw-redirect">subsidies</a>. This is largely because the beneficiaries of such subsidies are the general population, including the non-poor. Its effectiveness in poverty alleviation is diluted by the non-poor who enjoy the same subsidized prices.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[157]</a></sup> In some countries, fuel subsidies are a larger part of the budget than health and education.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[158]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[159]</a></sup> A 2008 study concluded that the money spent on in-kind transfers in India in a year could lift all India’s poor out of poverty for that year if transferred directly.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[160]</a></sup> The primary obstacle argued to avoid direct cash transfers is the impractically for poor countries of such large and direct transfers. In practice, payments determined by complex iris scanning are used by war-torn <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Congo" title="Democratic Republic of Congo" class="mw-redirect">Congo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[161]</a></sup> while India is phasing out its fuel subsidies in favor of direct transfers.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[162]</a></sup> Additionally, in aid models, the <a href="/wiki/Famine_relief" title="Famine relief">famine relief</a> model increasing used by aid groups calls for giving cash or cash vouchers to the hungry to pay local farmers instead of buying food from donor countries, often required by law, as it wastes money on transport costs.<sup id="cite_ref-csmonitor_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-csmonitor-164">[163]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wfp_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wfp-165">[164]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_freedoms">Economic freedoms</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In Canada, it takes two days, two registration procedures, and $280 to open a business,<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[165]</a></sup> while an entrepreneur in <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> must pay $2,696 in fees, wait 82 business days, and go through 20 procedures to do the same. Such costly barriers favor big firms at the expense of small enterprises, where most jobs are created.<sup id="cite_ref-cato_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cato-167">[166]</a></sup> Often, businesses have to bribe government officials even for routine activities, which is, in effect, a tax on business.<sup id="cite_ref-macroeconomics1_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-macroeconomics1-168">[167]</a></sup> Noted reductions in poverty in recent decades has occurred in China and <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> mostly as a result of the abandonment of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Collective_farming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Collective farming (page does not exist)">collective farming</a> in China and the ending of the <a href="/wiki/Central_planning" title="Central planning" class="mw-redirect">central planning</a> model known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=License_Raj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="License Raj (page does not exist)">License Raj</a> in India.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc1_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc1-169">[168]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[169]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[170]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> concludes that governments and feudal elites extending to the poor the right to the land that they live and use is ‘the key to reducing poverty’ citing that land rights greatly increase poor people’s wealth, in some cases doubling it.<sup id="cite_ref-landrights_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-landrights-172">[171]</a></sup> Although approaches varied, the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> said the key issues were security of tenure and ensuring land transactions costs were low.<sup id="cite_ref-landrights_172-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-landrights-172">[171]</a></sup>
</p><p>Greater access to markets brings more income to the poor. <a href="/wiki/Road" title="Road">Road</a> infrastructure has a direct impact on poverty.<sup id="cite_ref-GCR_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GCR-173">[172]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[173]</a></sup> Additionally, migration from poorer countries resulted in $328 billion sent from richer to poorer countries in 2010, more than double the $120 billion in official aid flows from <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD" class="mw-redirect">OECD</a> members. In 2011, India got $52 billion from its <a href="/wiki/Diaspora" title="Diaspora">diaspora</a>, more than it took in <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[174]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Financial_services">Financial services</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kiwanja_uganda_charging_1.jpg" title="File:Kiwanja uganda charging 1.jpg">File:Kiwanja uganda charging 1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Information_and_communication_technologies_for_development" title="Information and communication technologies for development">Information and communication technologies for development</a> help to fight poverty.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Microloans, made famous by the <a href="/wiki/Grameen_Bank" title="Grameen Bank">Grameen Bank</a>, is where small amounts of money are loaned to farmers or villages, mostly women, who can then obtain physical capital to increase their economic rewards. However, microlending has been criticized for making hyperprofits off the poor even from its founder, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Yunus" title="Muhammad Yunus">Muhammad Yunus</a>, and in India, which has seen a growing wave of defaults and suicides.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[175]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[176]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[177]</a></sup>
</p><p>Those in poverty place overwhelming importance on having a safe place to save money, much more so than receiving loans.<sup id="cite_ref-time.com_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-time.com-179">[178]</a></sup> Additionally, a large part of <a href="/wiki/Microfinance" title="Microfinance">microfinance</a> loans are spent not on investments but on products that would usually be paid by a <a href="/wiki/Checking_account" title="Checking account" class="mw-redirect">checking</a> or <a href="/wiki/Savings_account" title="Savings account">savings account</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-time.com_179-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-time.com-179">[178]</a></sup> Microsavings are designs to make savings products available for the poor, who make small deposits. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mobile_banking&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mobile banking (page does not exist)">Mobile banking</a> utilizes the wide availability of mobile phones to address the problem of the heavy regulation and costly maintenance of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saving_account&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saving account (page does not exist)">saving accounts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-time.com_179-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-time.com-179">[178]</a></sup> This usually involves a network of agents of mostly shopkeepers, instead of bank branches, would take deposits in cash and translate these onto a virtual account on customers' phones. Cash transfers can be done between phones and issued back in cash with a small commission, making <a href="/w/index.php?title=Remittance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Remittance (page does not exist)">remittances</a> safer.<sup id="cite_ref-safaricom_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-safaricom-180">[179]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Beggar_India.jpg" title="File:Beggar India.jpg">File:Beggar India.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Dalit <a href="/wiki/Beggar" title="Beggar" class="mw-redirect">beggars</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jaipur" title="Jaipur">Jaipur</a>, capital of <a href="/wiki/Rajasthan" title="Rajasthan">Rajasthan</a>, India. An “untouchable” or <a href="/wiki/Dalit" title="Dalit">Dalit</a> is considered outside of the <a href="/wiki/Caste" title="Caste">caste</a> system.</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_factors_to_productivity">Cultural factors to productivity</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Cultural factors, such as discrimination of various kinds, can negatively affect productivity such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ageism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ageism (page does not exist)">age discrimination</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stereotype&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stereotype (page does not exist)">stereotyping</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[180]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sexism" title="Sexism">gender discrimination</a>, <a href="/wiki/Racism" title="Racism">racial discrimination</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Caste" title="Caste">caste discrimination</a>. <a href="/wiki/Max_Weber" title="Max Weber">Max Weber</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Modernization_theory" title="Modernization theory">modernization theory</a> suggest that cultural <a href="/w/index.php?title=Value_(personal_and_cultural)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Value (personal and cultural) (page does not exist)">values</a> could affect economic success.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[181]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[182]</a></sup> However, researchers<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Who&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Who (page does not exist)">Template:Who</a> have gathered evidence that suggest that values are not as deeply ingrained and that changing economic opportunities explain most of the movement into and out of poverty, as opposed to shifts in values.<sup id="cite_ref-kerbo2006a_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kerbo2006a-184">[183]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate_change">Climate change</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
A report published in 2013 by the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, with support from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Climate_%26_Development_Knowledge_Network&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Climate &amp; Development Knowledge Network (page does not exist)">Climate &amp; Development Knowledge Network</a>, found that climate change was likely to hinder future attempts to reduce poverty. The report presented the likely impacts of present day, 2°C and 4°C warming on agricultural production, water resources, coastal ecosystems and cities across Sub-Saharan Africa, South Asia and South East Asia. The impacts of a temperature rise of 2°C included: regular food shortages in Sub-Saharan Africa; shifting rain patterns in South Asia leaving some parts under water and others without enough water for power generation, irrigation or drinking; degradation and loss of reefs in South East Asia, resulting in reduced fish stocks; and coastal communities and cities more vulnerable to increasingly violent storms.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[184]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Voluntary_poverty">Voluntary poverty</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Giotto_-_Legend_of_St_Francis_-_-05-_-_Renunciation_of_Wordly_Goods.jpg" title="File:Giotto - Legend of St Francis - -05- - Renunciation of Wordly Goods.jpg">File:Giotto - Legend of St Francis - -05- - Renunciation of Wordly Goods.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">St. <a href="/wiki/Francis_of_Assisi" title="Francis of Assisi">Francis of Assisi</a> renounces his worldly goods in a painting attributed to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Giotto_di_Bondone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Giotto di Bondone (page does not exist)">Giotto di Bondone</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Among some individuals, poverty is considered a necessary or desirable condition, which must be embraced to reach certain spiritual, moral, or intellectual states. Poverty is often understood to be an essential element of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nekkhamma&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nekkhamma (page does not exist)">renunciation</a> in religions such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Buddhism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buddhism (page does not exist)">Buddhism</a> (only for monks, not for lay persons) and <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a>, whilst in Roman Catholicism it is one of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Evangelical_counsels&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Evangelical counsels (page does not exist)">evangelical counsels</a>.  The main aim of giving up materialistic world is to withdraw oneself from sensual pleasures (as they are fake and temporary in some religions). This self-invited poverty (or giving up pleasures) is different than the one caused by economic imbalance.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Benedict_XVI" title="Benedict XVI" class="mw-redirect">Benedict XVI</a> distinguishes “poverty <i>chosen</i>” (the poverty of spirit proposed by Jesus), and “poverty <i>to be fought</i>” (unjust and imposed poverty). He considers that the moderation implied in the former favors solidarity, and is a necessary condition so as to fight effectively to eradicate the abuse of the latter.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[185]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Organizations_and_campaigns">Organizations and campaigns</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-begin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-begin (page does not exist)">Template:Col-begin</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-1-of-2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-1-of-2 (page does not exist)">Template:Col-1-of-2</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Abahlali_baseMjondolo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abahlali baseMjondolo (page does not exist)">Abahlali baseMjondolo</a> – South African Shack dwellers' organisation
</li>

</li>

</li>

</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Grameen_Bank" title="Grameen Bank">Grameen Bank</a> A micro lending bank for the poor.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Habitat_for_Humanity_International&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Habitat for Humanity International (page does not exist)">Habitat for Humanity International</a>
</li>

</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Day_for_the_Eradication_of_Poverty&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Day for the Eradication of Poverty (page does not exist)">17 October: UN International Day for the Eradication of Poverty</a> (White Band Day 4)
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Food_Policy_Research_Institute&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Food Policy Research Institute (page does not exist)">International Food Policy Research Institute</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Col-2-of-2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Col-2-of-2 (page does not exist)">Template:Col-2-of-2</a>
</p>
<ul>
